para.sentence: Let f(t) be a locally integrable function on (0,\infty) , that is, \int_{\rho}^{T}f(t)\mathrm{d}t exists for all \rho and T satisfying 0<\rho<T<\infty.
The Mellin transform of f(t) is defined by \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right)=\int_{0}^{\infty}t^{z-1}f (t)\mathrm{d}t, when this integral converges.
The domain of analyticity of \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) is usually an infinite strip a<\Re z<b parallel to the imaginary axis.
The inversion formula is given by f(t)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{c-i\infty}^{c+i\infty}t^{-z}\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right)\mathrm{d}z, with a<c<b.

One of the two convolution integrals associated with the Mellin transform is of the form I(x)=\int_{0}^{\infty}f(t)\,h(xt)\mathrm{d}t, if x>0, and \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu I\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right)=\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f \mskip 3.0mu \left(1-z\right)\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z \right).

If \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(1-z\right) and \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) have a common strip of analyticity a<\Re z<b , then I(x)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{c-i\infty}^{c+i\infty}x^{-z}\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(1-z\right)\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z \right)\mathrm{d}z, where a<c<b.
When x=1 , this identity is a Parseval-type formula; compare ยง1.14(iv).

If \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(1-z\right) and \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) can be continued analytically to meromorphic functions in a left half-plane, and if the contour \Re z=c can be translated to \Re z=d with d<c , then I(x)=\sum\limits_{d<\Re z<c}\Residue\left[x^{-z}\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f \mskip 3.0mu \left(1-z\right)\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z \right)\right]+E(x), where E(x)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{d-i\infty}^{d+i\infty}x^{-z}\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(1-z\right)\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z \right)\mathrm{d}z.

The sum in (2.5.6) is taken over all poles of x^{-z}\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(1-z\right)\mathscr{M}\mskip- 3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) in the strip d<\Re z<c , and it provides the asymptotic expansion of I(x) for small values of x.

Similarly, if \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(1-z\right) and \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) can be continued analytically to meromorphic functions in a right half-plane, and if the vertical line of integration can be translated to the right, then we obtain an asymptotic expansion for I(x) for large values of x.

subsection.title: Extensions

para.sentence: Let f(t) and h(t) be locally integrable on (0,\infty) and f(t)\sim\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}a_{s}t^{\alpha_{s}}, if t\to 0+, where \Re\alpha_{s}>\Re\alpha_{s^{\prime}} for s>s^{\prime} , and \Re\alpha_{s}\to+\infty as s\to\infty.

Also, let h(t)\sim\exp\left(i\kappa t^{p}\right)\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}b_{s}t^{-\beta_{s}}, if t\to+\infty, where \kappa is real, p>0 , \Re\beta_{s}>\Re\beta_{s^{\prime}} for s>s^{\prime} , and \Re\beta_{s}\to+\infty as s\to\infty.
To ensure that the integral (2.5.3) converges we assume that f(t)=O\left(t^{-b}\right), if t\to+\infty, with b+\Re\beta_{0}>1 , and h(t)=O\left(t^{c}\right), if t\to 0+, with c+\Re\alpha_{0}>-1.

To apply the Mellin transform method outlined in ยง2.5(i), we require the transforms \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(1-z\right) and \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) to have a common strip of analyticity.
This, in turn, requires -b<\Re\alpha_{0} , -c<\Re\beta_{0} , and either -c<\Re\alpha_{0}+1 or 1-b<\Re\beta_{0}.
Following Handelsman and Lew (1970, 1971) we now give an extension of this method in which none of these conditions is required.
First, we introduce the truncated functions f_{1}(t) and f_{2}(t) defined by f_{1}(t)=\begin{cases}f(t),&0<t\leq 1,\\ 0,&1<t<\infty,\end{cases} , f_{2}(t)=f(t)-f_{1}(t).
Similarly, h_{1}(t)=\begin{cases}h(t),&0<t\leq 1,\\ 0,&1<t<\infty,\end{cases} , h_{2}(t)=h(t)-h_{1}(t).
With these definitions and the conditions (2.5.17)โ(2.5.20) the Mellin transforms converge absolutely and define analytic functions in the half-planes shown in Table 2.5.1.

para.sentence: Furthermore, \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f_{1}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) can be continued analytically to ameromorphic function on the entire z -plane, whose singularities are simple poles at -\alpha_{s} , s=0,1,2,\dots , with principal part a_{s}/\left(z+\alpha_{s}\right).
By Table 2.5.1,
\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f_{2}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) is an analytic function in the half-plane \Re z<b.

Hence we can extend the definition of the Mellin transform of f by setting \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right)=\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f _{1}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right)+\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f_{2}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) for \Re z<b.
The extended transform \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) has the same properties as \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f_{1}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) in the half-plane \Re z<b.

Similarly, if \kappa=0 in (2.5.18), then \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h_{2}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) can be continued analytically to a meromorphic function on the entire z -plane with simple poles at \beta_{s} , s=0,1,2,\dots , with principal part -b_{s}/\left(z-\beta_{s}\right).
Alternatively, if \kappa\neq 0 in (2.5.18), then \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h_{2}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) can be continued analytically to an entire function.

Since \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h_{1}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) is analytic for \Re z>-c by Table 2.5.1, the analytically-continued \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h_{2}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) allows us to extend the Mellin transform of h via \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right)=\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h _{1}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right)+\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h_{2}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) in the same half-plane.

From (2.5.26) and (2.5.28), it follows that both \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(1-z\right) and \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) are defined in the half-plane \Re z>\max(1-b,-c).
We are now ready to derive the asymptotic expansion of the integral I(x) in (2.5.3) as x\to\infty.
First we note that I(x)=\sum\limits_{j,k=1}^{2}I_{jk}(x), where I_{jk}(x)=\int_{0}^{\infty}f_{j}(t)h_{k}(xt)\mathrm{d}t.
By direct computation I_{21}(x)=0, if for x\geq 1.

Next from Table 2.5.1 we observe that the integrals for the transform pair \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f_{j}\mskip 3.0mu \left(1-z\right) and \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h_{k}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) are absolutely convergent in the domain D_{jk} specified in Table2.5.2, and these domains are nonempty as a consequence of (2.5.19) and (2.5.20).

para.sentence: For simplicity, write G_{jk}(z)=\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f_{j}\mskip 3.0mu \left(1-z\right)\mathscr{M }\mskip-3.0mu h_{k}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right).
From Table 2.5.2, we see that each G_{jk}(z) is analytic in the domain D_{jk}.
Furthermore, each G_{jk}(z) has an analytic or meromorphic extension to a half-plane containing D_{jk}.

Now suppose that there is a real number p_{jk} in D_{jk} such that the Parseval formula (2.5.5) applies and I_{jk}(x)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{p_{jk}-i\infty}^{p_{jk}+i\infty}x^{-z}G_{jk}(z )\mathrm{d}z.

If, in addition, there exists a number q_{jk}>p_{jk} such that \sup_{p_{jk}\leq x\leq q_{jk}}\left|G_{jk}(x+iy)\right|\to 0, if y\to\pm\infty, then I_{jk}(x)=\sum_{p_{jk}<\Re z<q_{jk}}\Residue\left[-x^{-z}G_{jk}(z)\right]+E_{ jk}(x), where E_{jk}(x)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{q_{jk}-i\infty}^{q_{jk}+i\infty}x^{-z}G_{jk}(z )\mathrm{d}z=o\left(x^{-q_{jk}}\right) as x\to+\infty.
(The last order estimate follows from the RiemannโLebesgue lemma, ยง1.8(i).)The asymptotic expansion of I(x) is then obtained from (2.5.29).
For further discussion of this method and examples, seeWong (1989, Chapter 3), Paris and Kaminski (2001, Chapter 5), andBleistein and Handelsman (1975, Chapters 4 and 6).
The first reference also contains explicit expressions for the error terms, as do Soni (1980) andCarlson and Gustafson (1985).

The Mellin transform method can also be extended to derive asymptotic expansions of multidimensional integrals having algebraic or logarithmic singularities, or both; see Wong (1989, Chapter 3),Paris and Kaminski (2001, Chapter 7), and McClure and Wong (1987).
See alsoBrรผning (1984) for a different approach.
Let h(t) satisfy (2.5.18) and (2.5.20) with c>-1 , and consider the Laplace transform \mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(\zeta\right)=\int_{0}^{\infty}h(t) e^{-\zeta t}\mathrm{d}t.
Put x=1/\zeta and break the integration range at t=1 , as in (2.5.23) and (2.5.24).
Then \zeta\mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(\zeta\right)=I_{1}(x)+I_{2}(x), where I_{j}(x)=\int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-t}h_{j}(xt)\mathrm{d}t, if j=1,2.

Since \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu e^{-t}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right)=\Gamma\left(z\right) , by the Parseval formula (2.5.5), there are real numbers p_{1} and p_{2} such that -c<p_{1}<1 , p_{2}<\min(1,\Re\beta_{0}) , and I_{j}(x)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{p_{j}-i\infty}^{p_{j}+i\infty}x^{-z}\Gamma\left (1-z\right)\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h_{j}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right)\mathrm{d}z, if j=1,2.
Since \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) is analytic for \Re z>-c , by (2.5.14),

I_{1}(x)=\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h_{1}\mskip 3.0mu \left(1\right)x^{-1}+\frac{ 1}{2\pi i}\int_{\rho-i\infty}^{\rho+i\infty}x^{-z}\Gamma\left(1-z\right) \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h_{1}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right)\mathrm{d}z, for any \rho satisfying 1<\rho<2.

Similarly, since \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h_{2}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) can be continued analytically to a meromorphic function (when \kappa=0 ) or to an entire function (when \kappa\neq 0 ), we can choose \rho so that \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h_{2}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) has no poles in 1<\Re z\leq\rho<2.

Thus I_{2}(x)=\sum_{\Re\beta_{0}\leq\Re z\leq 1}\Residue\left[-x^{-z}\Gamma\left(1- z\right)\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h_{2}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right)\right]+\frac{ 1}{2\pi i}\int_{\rho-i\infty}^{\rho+i\infty}x^{-z}\Gamma\left(1-z\right) \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h_{2}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right)\mathrm{d}z.

On substituting (2.5.41) and (2.5.42) into (2.5.38), we obtain \mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(\zeta\right)=\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0 mu h_{1}\mskip 3.0mu \left(1\right)+\sum_{\Re\beta_{0}\leq\Re z\leq 1}\Residue \left[-\zeta^{z-1}\Gamma\left(1-z\right)\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h_{2}\mskip 3. 0mu \left(z\right)\right]+\sum\limits_{1<\Re z<l}\Residue\left[-\zeta^{z-1} \Gamma\left(1-z\right)\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) \right]+\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{l-\delta-i\infty}^{l-\delta+i\infty}\zeta^{z-1} \Gamma\left(1-z\right)\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) \mathrm{d}z, where l ( \geq 2 ) is an arbitrary integer and \delta is an arbitrary small positive constant.
The last term is clearly O\left(\zeta^{l-\delta-1}\right) as \zeta\to 0+.

If \kappa=0 in (2.5.18) and c>-1 in (2.5.20), and if none of the exponents in (2.5.18) are positive integers, then the expansion (2.5.43) gives the following useful result: \mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(\zeta\right)\sim\sum_{n=0}^{\infty }b_{n}\Gamma\left(1-\beta_{n}\right)\zeta^{\beta_{n}-1}+\sum\limits_{n=0}^{ \infty}\frac{(-\zeta)^{n}}{n!}\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(n+1 \right), if \zeta\to 0+.
\mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(\zeta\right)=\int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{e^{-\zeta t}}{1+t}\mathrm{d}t, if \Re\zeta>0.
With h(t)=1/(1+t) , we have \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right)=\pi\csc\left(\pi z\right) for 0<\Re z<1.
In the notation of (2.5.18) and (2.5.20),
\kappa=0 , \beta_{s}=s+1 , and c=0.

Straightforward calculation gives \Residue_{z=k}\left[-\zeta^{z-1}\Gamma\left(1-z\right)\pi\csc\left(\pi z\right )\right]=\left(-\ln\zeta+\psi\left(k\right)\right)\dfrac{\zeta^{k-1}}{(k-1)!} , where \psi\left(z\right)=\Gamma'\left(z\right)/\Gamma\left(z\right).

\Residue_{z=1}\left[-\zeta^{z-1}\Gamma\left(1-z\right)\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h_{2}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right)\right]=\left(-\ln\zeta-\gamma\right)-\mathscr {M}\mskip-3.0mu h_{1}\mskip 3.0mu \left(1\right), where \gamma is Eulerโs constant (ยง5.2(ii)).

Insertion of these results into (2.5.43) yields \mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(\zeta\right)\sim(-\ln\zeta)\sum_{k =0}^{\infty}\frac{\zeta^{k}}{k!}+\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\psi\left(k+1\right)\frac{ \zeta^{k}}{k!}, if \zeta\to 0+.
To verify (2.5.48) we may use \mathscr{L}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(\zeta\right)=e^{\zeta}E_{1}\left( \zeta\right); compare (6.2.2) and (6.6.3).

For examples in which the integral defining the Mellin transform \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) does not exist for any value of z , seeWong (1989, Chapter 3), Bleistein and Handelsman (1975, Chapter 4), andHandelsman and Lew (1970).
